pullRequest.title: Performance test Project for service bus track 1 and track 2
pullRequest.bodyText:
Create track 1 performance test sub module.


Create track 2 performance test sub module.


fixes #9919

commit.message: Adding test for track1 as well.

nodes.bodyText: Can we use the full name via ReceiveAndDeleteMessageTest.class.getName()? It'll make refactoring easier.

@@ -0,0 +1,34 @@
+# Azure Storage Performance test client library for Java
+
+Represents Performance tests for Azure Service Bus SDK for Java.
+
+## Getting started
+
+### Prerequisites
+
+- Java Development Kit (JDK) with version 8 or above
+
+### Adding the package to your product
+
+
+## Key concepts
+
+
+## Examples
+
+## Troubleshooting
+
+## Next steps
+
+## Contributing
+
+If you would like to become an active contributor to this project please follow the instructions provided in [Microsoft
+Azure Projects Contribution Guidelines](http://azure.github.io/guidelines.html).
+
+1. Fork it
+1. Create your feature branch (`git checkout -b my-new-feature`)
+1. Commit your changes (`git commit -am 'Add some feature'`)
+1. Push to the branch (`git push origin my-new-feature`)
+1. Create new Pull Request
+
+![Impressions](https://azure-sdk-impressions.azurewebsites.net/api/impressions/azure-sdk-for-java%2Fsdk%2Fservicebus%2Fperf-test-core%2FREADME.png)

nodes.bodyText: nit: uneeded new lines.
nit: unneeded new lines.
Why are we using a flatmap here? It can easily be an IntStream. messages is not thread-safe either, so I would not expect us to use it in a flatMap.
Why aren't we using the async sender here for Track 1?
Similarly. This isn't using completeable futures correctly. You can bridge a completeable future into a mono and return that.
Why are we sending one at a time instead of using sending an iterable? You can use an IntStream to create all the messages.

nodes.bodyText: Use the async option. sendBatchAsync. There is a static method that changes it to the appropriate reactor type
Same with all these. We should be using async methods.

Since the messages will be deleted in SB once received, we need to ensure there are enough messages to be received by all concurrent threads.
We should take into account, the number of parallel threads specified in options here.
And multiply the total messages to send by the number of parallel threads.

cleanupAsync shouldn't be required here. This should be used only when you want to do cleanup after each thread finishes execution.
You have the globalCleanupAsync below where you're closing the sender.
That will get executed after the perf test finishes completely.
Wrap the cleanup logic in Mono.defer and then chain that with super.globalCleanupAsync call.
Call super.globalSetupAsync first and then chain that with setup logic in a mono defer call.
Call super.globalSetupAsync first and then chain that with setup logic in a mono defer call.
if the messages are deleted after receivng then multiply total messages with number of parallel threads specified here. To ensure enough messages are in SB to be received by all threads.

cleanupAsync shouldn't be required here. This should be used only when you want to do cleanup after each thread finishes execution.
You have the globalCleanupAsync below where you're closing the sender.
That will get executed after the perf test finishes.
Wrap in Mono defer then chain with super.globalCleanupAsync.

Either construct this in Semd Message Test COnstructor.
OR make this static so, multiple threads can refer to same message instance to be sent to SB.
If you make this static, then use it as a static reference in your test.
Call super.globalSetupAsync first then chain the setup logic.

Either construct this in Semd Message Test COnstructor.
OR make this static so, multiple threads can refer to same message instance to be sent to SB.
If you make this static, then use it as a static reference in your test.
same comment for all globalSetupAsync as previous ones.
Is there a reason we have this suppression rather than removing the local variable? Our goal is to limit spotbug excludes as much as possible.

nodes.bodyText: I'm confused. Why are we postfixing this or even getting the size?
Why not use the completeable future, compose it, and then in the last step, bring it into the reactor world?
I'm not sure why we are doing busy work here. it doesn't match the sync one either rather than returning messages.count() or returning Mono.empty() instead of constantly using .then()
You can combine Completable futures. If the send fails to close, then the receiver won't bother being closed either.

I'm not sure why you need this? You're just returning the message over and over again. You can do a foreach loop and add them rather than "mapping to an object". How do you discern between different messages?
I see you have a client logger but are using system.out,println instead.
The .handle operator would be more appropriate than just returning messages (because you're not actually mapping anything) and chaining it with .then()
Same comment for the each loop.
This will never fire off because it is not subscribed to.
Same comment about composing rather than chaining .then().
What I was thinking of was: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/CompletableFuture.html#allOf-java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture...-
Remove this extra statement. Fix spacing in sentence.
you would use sink.error
If the future fails, the global cleanup will not run... Why not Mono.when() same with other instances.
You can combine multiple completeable futures.
Why are we not checking the received msg count being > 0 here like other places ?
Is Mono.defer what you intended to use it for? For each new subscriber, it'll supply another mono.
You need to format this document, there are two spaces here.
You should use placeholders {} for logging in slf4j, so it's not evaluated if the log level isn't set.
Similarly, do you intend to use Mono.defer and provide a new Mono for each downstream subscriber?
This has a running time of 2n because you go through the list to get the complete operation and then create another list. You could do it in a single iteration, i believe.
is this ever returned?
Why not use thenCompose versus thenAccept? You're putting a blocking method call inside an async method.
Why do you need Mono.when? There's only one item.
Format document. There are two spaces here.
Have you tried .thenComposeAsync?
Why '-mr" and "-ms"? vs "-r" "--receive" and "-s", "--send"? It's a lot of characters to type.

+# Azure ServiceBus Performance test client library for Java
+
+Represents Performance tests for Azure Service Bus SDK for Java.
+
+## Getting started
+
+### Prerequisites

+- Java Development Kit (JDK) with version 8 or above
+
+### Adding the package to your product

+

+Azure Projects Contribution Guidelines](http://azure.github.io/guidelines.html).

+3. Commit your changes (`git commit -am 'Add some feature'`)
